column1: Day 1. We believe rhyming statements are more truthful. ('What sobriety conceals, alcohol reveals.')
Day 2. Yawning is contagious only among people who feel emotionally close.
Day 3. We remember the first and last items in a list best. It’s called the serial position effect.
Day 4. Our brains fill in visual gaps automatically—sometimes seeing things that aren't there (like blind spot filling).
Day 5. We overestimate how much people notice us. This is called the spotlight effect.
Day 6. We make decisions based on how information is framed—even if it's the same fact. (90% fat-free vs. 10% fat).
Day 7. We remember emotionally wrong memories just because they feel right. That's the illusion of truth.
Day 8. We mimic others' facial expressions without realizing, called mirroring—it builds unconscious rapport.
Day 9. Our short-term memory can only hold about 7 things at once. That’s why phone numbers are the length they are.
Day 10. We think we’re above average at most things. Statistically impossible. It's the superiority illusion.
Day 11. We believe rhyming statements are more truthful. ('What sobriety conceals, alcohol reveals.')

Day 318. We mimic others' facial expressions without realizing, called mirroring—it builds unconscious rapport.
Day 319. Our short-term memory can only hold about 7 things at once. That’s why phone numbers are the length they are.
Day 320. We think we’re above average at most things. Statistically impossible. It's the superiority illusion.
Day 321. We believe rhyming statements are more truthful. ('What sobriety conceals, alcohol reveals.')
Day 322. Yawning is contagious only among people who feel emotionally close.
Day 323. We remember the first and last items in a list best. It’s called the serial position effect.
Day 324. Our brains fill in visual gaps automatically—sometimes seeing things that aren't there (like blind spot filling).
Day 325. We overestimate how much people notice us. This is called the spotlight effect.
